pullrequest.title: Add ability to save worlds to SDFormat

content.raw: The `initFile` call is expensive because it loads a file from disk. On Gazebo-classic, we usually did this once at startup and reused the resulting element at runtime. This may not be the most time-consuming part of the saving process, but it's something to consider.
content.html: The initFile call is expensive because it loads a file from disk. On Gazebo-classic, we usually did this once at startup and reused the resulting element at runtime. This may not be the most time-consuming part of the saving process, but it's something to consider.

pullrequest.title: Add ability to save worlds to SDFormat

content.raw: I'm having a hard time following the comments here. Maybe a couple of examples in the comment would help? Such as  "For example, if the uri is https://.../model_name and modelDir is /home/..., then..."

pullrequest.title: Add ability to save worlds to SDFormat

content.raw:
I'll add this example:
If the uri is `https://example.org/1.0/test/models/Backpack` the path to the directory containing the sdf file (modelDir) will be: `$HOME/.ignition/fuel/example.org/test/models/Backpack/1/` and the basename of the directory is "1", which is the model version.

I have verified that this assumption will not always hold true. For example, if I move `$HOME/.ignition/fuel/example.org/test/models/Backpack/1/` to `/tmp/test/` and create a symlink `$HOME/.ignition/fuel/example.org/test/models/Backpack/1/ -> /tmp/test`, the filepath of the model.sdf will actually be `/tmp/test/model.sdf`. 

I don't know if anyone would want to do that though. I have used a symlink to point `$HOME/.ignition` to another hard disk to save space on my SSD, but I doubt that users would create a symlink at the level of a model's version directory.
content.html:
I'll add this example: If the uri is https://example.org/1.0/test/models/Backpack the path to the directory containing the sdf file (modelDir) will be: $HOME/.ignition/fuel/example.org/test/models/Backpack/1/ and the basename of the directory is "1", which is the model version.

I have verified that this assumption will not always hold true. For example, if I move $HOME/.ignition/fuel/example.org/test/models/Backpack/1/ to /tmp/test/ and create a symlink $HOME/.ignition/fuel/example.org/test/models/Backpack/1/ -> /tmp/test, the filepath of the model.sdf will actually be /tmp/test/model.sdf.

I don't know if anyone would want to do that though. I have used a symlink to point $HOME/.ignition to another hard disk to save space on my SSD, but I doubt that users would create a symlink at the level of a model's version directory.

content.raw: I loaded and saved `fuel.sdf`, and the `gazebo` model is not properly saved because it uses relative paths. Is this case supposed to be covered by this PR?

pullrequest.title: Add ability to save worlds to SDFormat

content.raw: hmm, I hadn't considered that. That would mean we have to update all URIs in the model. It would be nice to have be part of this PR. I'll try to get it in today.
content.html: hmm, I hadn't considered that. That would mean we have to update all URIs in the model. It would be nice to have be part of this PR. I'll try to get it in today.

pullrequest.title: Add ability to save worlds to SDFormat

content.raw: Fixed in ced58d7. Per the discussions [here](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/558/accept-relative-path-in/diff), I assumed that URIs that start with `file://` are always absolute paths and, therefore, do not need to be updated. Let me know if that's incorrect.
content.html: Fixed in ced58d7. Per the discussions here, I assumed that URIs that start with file:// are always absolute paths and, therefore, do not need to be updated. Let me know if that's incorrect.

pullrequest.title: Add ability to save worlds to SDFormat

content.raw:
@{557058:90bc87b0-2886-4377-a17c-3a6629a697ff} , I added a path validator on 89a7882. 

* The ok button is only enabled if the path starts with `file:///` and ends with `.sdf`
* The user can't type a URL that wouldn't be at least partially valid. For example, they can't type `banana`, they keys won't register. But they can type `file:///tmp`, because that's a valid beginning for a path.

The user can still write invalid paths, like `file:///lala.sdf`, and the UI won't explain what happened, but I think that was also the case before. And this URI scheme will be confusing for Windows users - I suggest we revisit this later.
content.html:
@Addisu Z. Taddese , I added a path validator on 89a7882.

  • The ok button is only enabled if the path starts with file:/// and ends with .sdf
  • The user can't type a URL that wouldn't be at least partially valid. For example, they can't type banana, they keys won't register. But they can type file:///tmp, because that's a valid beginning for a path.

The user can still write invalid paths, like file:///lala.sdf, and the UI won't explain what happened, but I think that was also the case before. And this URI scheme will be confusing for Windows users - I suggest we revisit this later.
